title: The Dwarf

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on paper, lined to canvas.

description: Although Georges Rouault is perhaps best known for his religious imagery, he also painted characters living on the fringes of society. Drawing on the work of such artists as Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and Edgar Degas, Rouault often depicted circus performers; their tragic-comic essence allowed him to sympathetically comment on the complexities of the human condition. The Dwarf, along with many of Rouault’s other paintings from this period, began as a work on paper that the artist mounted onto canvas during its making and continued to work. This unusual process, in addition to the application of several uneven layers of thick and colorful paint, allowed Rouault to achieve highly expressive effects.
medium_display: Oil on paper, lined to canvas
credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Max Epstein

La Renaissance 20:10–12 (October–December 1937), p. 2 (ill.), as Le nain, n.d.

exhibition_history:
New York, Bignou Gallery, Paintings and Gouaches by Georges Rouault, May 1940, n.p., cat. 14 (ill.), as Le Nain, n.d.

Los Angeles, Dalzell Hatfield Galleries, Rouault, August 15–September 15, 1940, n.p., cat. 3, as Le Nain, n.d.

Boston, Institute of Modern Art, Georges Rouault, Retrospective Loan Exhibition, November 1940, p. 26, cat. 39, as The Dwarf, n.d.; traveled to Washington, D.C., The Phillips Memorial Gallery and San Francisco Museum of Art, March 1941.

New York, Museum of Modern Art, Paintings and Prints, Georges Rouault, 1945, pp. 86 and 117, cat. 73 (ill.), as Dwarf, c. 1936.

Grand Rapids, Mich., Grand Rapids Art Gallery, Georges Rouault, April 11–May 2, 1947. 

Dallas Museum of Fine Arts, The Winterbotham Collection of 20th Century European Paintings from the Art Institute of Chicago, October 8–November 5, 1949, no cat.

Brussels, Belgium, Palais des Beaux-Arts, Georges Rouault: Retrospective, March–May 1952, pp. 36 (ill.) and 54, cat. 42, as Le Nain, n.d.; traveled to Amsterdam, Stedelijik Museum, May 9–June 30, 1952, and Paris, Musée National d’Art Moderne, July 9–October 26, 1952, p. 27, cat. 55, pl. X, as Le Nain, n.d.

Cleveland, Museum of Art, Rouault: Retrospective Exhibition, January 27–March 14, 1953, p. 29, as The Dwarf, c. 1936; traveled to New York, Museum of Modern Art, March 31–June 1, 1953, and the Los Angeles County Museum, June 29–August 15, 1953.

Milan, Galleria d’Arte Moderna, Padiglione d’Arte Contemporanea, Mostra di Georges Rouault, April–June 1954, p. 18, cat. 54, pl. XXVII, as Il Nano, 1936.

La Jolla, Calif., La Jolla Museum of Art, Works of Rouault: Paintings and Graphics, September 25–November 1, 1964, n.p., cat. 14 (ill.), as The Dwarf, c. 1936.

Arts Council of Great Britain (organizer), Rouault, 1966, pp. 48 and 49 (ill.), cat. 67, as The Dwarf (Le Nain), 1937; exhibited at Edinburgh, Royal Scottish Academy, August 21–September 10, 1966, and London, Tate Gallery, October 8¬–November 13, 1966.

Munich, Haus der Kunst, Georges Rouault, 1871–1958, March 23–May 12, 1974, p. 39, cat. 53, as Der Zwerg (Le nain), 1936; traveled to Manchester, City Art Galleries, June 4–July 28, 1974, cat. 37.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Cézanne to Picasso: Ambroise Vollard, Patron of the Avant-Garde, February 17–May 13, 2007, pp. 400–401, cat. 180, fig. 182, as The Dwarf, 1937; traveled to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, September 13, 2006–January 7, 2007, and the Musée d’Orsay, Paris, June 18–September 16, 2007.
provenance_text: The artist; Ambroise Vollard (1867–1939), Paris, probably on May 2, 1937 [La Renaissance 1937 and New York 2006]. Bignou Gallery, New York, by May 1940 [New York 1940]. Samuel Marx (1885–1964) and Florene May Schoenborn (1903–1995), New York and Chicago, from Apr. 5, 1943. Sold through Dalzell Hatfield Galleries, Los Angeles to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1946.
